Hi Barry,
     It's an interesting study to be sure although I'm not aware =
of 
too much available literature to 'study'.  The 'Bushido' magazines 
fro=
m Robert Benson (1980's) had a lot of great information, and the 
1976 Tai =
Kai from San Francisco book has a lot of information also (I 
believe there=
's a copy at Bridge of Dreams).  They show up on Ebay 
from time to time al=
so.
     What I was referring to with the kozuka was the effect of 
removin=
g of gold revealing the substrate for effent, which you can 
see better the=
re than on the menuki where there is definatley wear 
involved also.  Ezo m=
enuki were fabricated on a positive mould from 
thin copper sheet, then the=
 gold was applied using a mercury 
technique (probably heat evaporation), t=
hen burnished with a needle 
to get the effect.  Uttori by definition is at=
tachment of the inly 
around the edges only, although I would imagine there=
 is some form of 
burnishing or other form of adhesion involved as well.  A=
s far as the 
wear to the menuki, hell, I hope I look that good when I'm th=
at old!

Pete

PS:  I have a feeling they are older than Edo due to the pos=
ts both 
being open -- possibly Jim would know?

blem".  I
